CHANGE.ITEM: *Proofed title page(s). *Reviewed structure. *Checked division-marking material at heads and feet of divisions (HEADS, CLOSER, OPENER, ARGUMENT, EPIGRAPH, SIGNED, BYLINE, etc.). *Added TYPEs to DIVs in order to validate. *Checked for N=""s. *Checked s. *Checked placement and completeness of PBs. *Checked for foreign, damage and missing-page GAPs, #, --. *Checked for LBs, startqs / endqs, q;s, {que}s, ABBRs and Qs. *Checked for FIGUREs and decorated initials. *Checked proofsheets and made corrections found there. *Corrected s and s etc. *Converted s to GAP DESC="illegible" RESP="[vendor name]". *Revalidated.

DIV1.P: THE GOLDEN PIPPIN: AN ENGLISH BURLETTA, IN THREE ACTS.
As it is performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed for T. BECKET, in the Strand.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: IT is but Justice to the absent Author to declare, in contradiction to many idle Reports, and injurious Paragraphs that in this Piece, as in his former, he only proposed an innocent Burlesque; never thinking Ribaldry, Profaneness, or Per∣sonal Satire, a proper Entertainment for the Public, to whose experienced Candour and Indulgence he submits the following BURLETTA.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I. SCENE I.
DIV2.P: The Curtain rising, discovers a Splendid Pavilion in the Clouds; JUNO, PALLAS, and VENUS at a Card-Table playing at Tredrille, on one Side a Table, with Goblets, &c. IRIS, in Waiting, During a Symphony, VENUS shuffles and deals. PALLAS frets at her bad Cards.
DIV2.STAGE: AIR. TRIO. Franoesco. PALLAS, JUNO, VENUS.

L.HI: I Pass—I've done so all the night.
You scarcely Pass one hand in ten.
The Cards owe me a spite.
This Lady knows you;—so do I.
You dealt the Cards—and we could spy.
But losers must have leave to pout.
But losers must ha' leave to pout.

DIV2.STAGE: (Juno and Pallas rise in heat, and come forward. Venus sits still, counting and pocketing her gains.)

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Hang cards!

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: As I'm a sinner!
I haven't—since last Christmas—ris'n a winner.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: That's hard!—So bad a run may well chagrin one:
Venus is quite a dab.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Dab!—She's—a keen one; At all games—plays th' whole game.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Aye, aye!

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Match none has; For sleight of hand,—will slip an ace—with Jonas.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Gambles deep too!

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Well may—who never loses: At Putt, poor girls!—sh' as beggar'd the Nine Muses;
Fine as a Queen o' ginger-bread—parades it;
But ne'er has paid the wages of her Maids yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Like enough—for the Graces,—and 'tis scandalous,
Go mother-naked.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Skin-flint!—so to randle us! 'Twould vex a saint.—

L.HI: Has pick'd up, here, of chousing us;

LG.L: By Pam! I'll pluck a crow wi' you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Nay,—Pallas!

DIV2.STAGE: [Venus advances to them, smiling jocosely at Pallas.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Miss,—you're—funny, Poor dear!—has't lost it' temper with it' money? ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Pert chitty face! 'cause leud fops call you—pretty;
You fancy those—patch-clenches—smart—and witty.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Pretty!—the fools!—do they, indeed?—Ah, tell us.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Conceited moppet!

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Sure, Miss,—you a'n't jealous.

DIV2.STAGE: [Takes out a pocket-glass, and views herself affectedly.]

L.HI: Can I help it?—No, not I;—
Some good luck too—'tis my duty
If the Smarts of the Sky
No, no—If I do, may I die.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Don't rouze me, Bold-face!—if your tongue's so flippant, I'll take y' a chuck—as shall chop off the tip on't.

DIV2.STAGE: [Pallas advances upon her; she takes shelter behind Juno.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: I'll swear the peace:—keep at arms-length, Virago!
She'll brain me, Mâm!

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: —Well, had I don't long a-go.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven
SP.P: Your tongue's no slan∣der—for that, not a button
Care I;—but I can't stand your fist o' mutton.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Nuts to me, This—I hope, 'twill be a scuffle;
My stars! what was't cou'd thus your tempers ruffle?

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Her gibes,

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Her rants.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Don't snouch then!

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Don't you hector!

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Faults on both sides—sit down—come, I'll direct here.
And Iris!—stir, wench!—fill about the nectar.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal. Venus—
SP.P: your quips would Patient Grisel canker,
Howe'er, shake hands!

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Here, Miss, I bear no rancour.

DIV2.STAGE: AIR IV. Touch the Thing, you Bastard.
(All sit, and Iris serves them with Nectar.

L.HI: Or shew me that glib speaker,
With her mouth full of liquor.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE changes to a Wild Heath.
Enter Momus, in the habit of the Antique Court Jester. Walks to and fro impatiently.

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: By Jingo! if Erynnis—from the Hespe∣rides,
Steals me the Dragon's Apple-we'll ha'merry days. Augh!—ho!—oa!—
Court's grown damn'd hum-drum:—Jove, poor Noodle!
Does nought but muddle.—
Juno too—turn'd so—mim, forsooth, Butter will scarce melt in her mouth.
But th' Apple—yes—I'll throw—that squib among 'em—
Shall stir the humours—as a wasp had stung 'em,

DIV2.STAGE: AIR V. Behind the Bush in the Garden,

L.HI: The turn of a straw or a pin does;
And fling Heaven out o' the windows.

LG.L: Jove of my puppets but is chief;

L.HI: I doat on a snug bit o' mischief.

DIV2.STAGE: [To him enter running, as from pursuit, Erynnis, holding the Golden Apple in her hand, and ha∣bited as an old witch.]

SP.SPEAKER: Ery.
SP.P: Here, Momus, 'tis—at last;—I'm all o'er dripping.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: Good Hag!—Now quick, to Juno's pa∣lace tripping,
Amongst the three Sultanas drop this Pippin.

SP.SPEAKER: Ery.
SP.P: That Dragon! Oh! we've had a-do most hellish,
Burn him!—for Pippins he has spoil'd my re∣lish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: No fear;—I'll fool him with some rig∣ma-rol,—
Pat on his back, and scratch his pol.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ery.
SP.P: But I—(in terror)

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: You—must plump down to Hell,—to Pluto;
I've writ a card to him.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ery.
SP.P: Any where,—in tuto.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: Off! off!

DIV2.STAGE: [She takes to her heels, Momus skulks aside.—En∣ter impetuously the Dragon, searching on every side, during the symphony, to find her—then]—.

L.HI: Stop thief! Stop thief! Stop thief!

DIV2.STAGE: Momus comes forth, and accosts him familiarly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: Ha,—my old friend!—how is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Saw you that Beldam Erynnis scamper by?

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: Faith, Sir,—she—seldom Visits these parts:—yet pass'd—within this half-hour,
Hobbling—to Juno,—with some fruit—you—gave her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: She lies,—she stole it;—Gave! give her a halter!
Her due,—The thief!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: Stole! ay, an old defaulter.—
Sue out a warrant—

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Sue!—the Queen has got it,—I may go whistle—Piqued,—Repiqued,—Ca∣potted!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mo.
SP.P: Pluck up,—talk big to her,—
(Aside) I'll egg on this hot-head.

L.HI: Why then roar, and whisk your tail.
But I may be sent to Jail.
On my word, be won't demur.
And be sure you put it home t' her:
I shall pelt on, 'till I came t' her,
I shall pelt, &c. Thank you, Sir.

DIV2.STAGE: A knocking; then Juno's bell rings vehemently. Enter Iris running. Juno, Pallas, and Venus, enter on the other side.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: High time, Miss Lazyboots! where ha' you been lolloping?

SP.SPEAKER: Iris.
SP.P: Sure, Mem—at the first tinkle—I came galloping.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Who rapp'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Iris.
SP.P: Beau Cupid, Mêm, ask'd for Miss Pallas.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: For me? the Whelp!—I'd see him to the Gallows.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Gallows! Mâm.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Ay—'twill be his prank conclusive, As he goes on.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Mâm—she's downright abusive.

L.HI: But ah! Sweet Miss, your temper keep!
Your Peace my Boy shall ne'er invade;
Cupid shall not break your sleep,
You shall still remain a Maid.
Roses alone ne'er deck that thorn.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: I'd mince the blinkard—to a salmagondi.

DIV2.STAGE: [Enter Iris in a fright to Juno, THE APPLE in her hand.]

SP.SPEAKER: Iris.
SP.P: Oh! Mêm!

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Are you bewitch'd, Girl?—What has stunn'd ye?
Hast seen a Ghost—

SP.SPEAKER: Iris.
SP.P: Worse, Mêm—that hag—Erynnis.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Got in, d'ye say?—I wou'dn't for five guineas—

SP.SPEAKER: Iris.
SP.P: In troth, I think, that Witch the Devil-in-is.

DIV2.STAGE: AIR IX. Sweet, if you love me, &c.

L.HI: Told by the Porter and the Page,
You'd ha' thought she'd burst with rage.
Skips, I must see the Queen, and will—
Dear Ma'm, says I—the Queen is ill,

LG.L: Takes James's Powder, and Ward's Pill.

L.HI: Eccho'd they to all her askings.
To this Pippin bid her smell,
I'll engage she'll soon be well.
I box'd the Fox this morn, says she,

LG.L: And from th' Hesperian Dragon's Tree

L.HI: Hoik'd off with 't to her Majesty:

DIV2.STAGE: Juno and Pallas alternately admire the Apple, Venus desiring to look at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: With your leave, Mâm—

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Suppose that three shares equal We make—

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Oh—that—Erynnis might—not take well.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Bless us!—'t has grown—with an Inscription on it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Have the snails trac'd a tag of some—French sonnet?

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Nah, Miss; plain English—and to Me directed.
(insulting) A wind-fall, Ladies!—yet—one can't reject it.
So, poz—I will not have—my goods trisected.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Yours!

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Yours!

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: By what right?

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: What title?—Fool-y'!

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: What—when ye hear—will make you both look bluely.

DIV2.STAGE: Reads to them distinctly the Inscription, without RECITATIVE.
DIV2.Q: TO THE FAIREST IN HEAV'N, BE THIS APPLE GIV'N.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Stand clear, Mâm—let me to her—(to Venus) Shut your fly-trap, Your title I'll soon quash else—with a tight rap,

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: I bar blows—yet that Fruit I'll have,—depend on't;
'Tis mine, (to Venus) so, give it me—and there's an end on't.

L.HI: Yield; or beware, left rage, disdain,
The claim my rank, my charms sustain,

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Nay, Madam!—Sure—my claim's the more undoubted;
So (to Venus) give it me—and say no more about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Ladies, for Pow'r, Arms, Arts, I don't dispute ye,
But—all the world (bridling) gives me the crack for Beauty.

L.HI: Such rank conceit! It mads me.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: You Trapes!

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: You Demi-rep! you hatter'd Dowdy, Nam'd of a day with us—you're—

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Oh! No-body.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Two to one's odds;—but La∣dies,—since you crow so,
Let Jove judge.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Done!

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Done!

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: He's a Virtuoso
In female matters.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Troth—but so, so.

DIV2.STAGE: [Here they are alarm'd by a tumultuous roaring without. A Symphony of Terror and Con∣fusion; at the close bursts in the Hesperian Dragon. Juno and Venus run into a cor∣ner affrighted; Pallas undaunted.]

L.HI: I'll have it Crust and Crumb,
If up with her I come,

DIV2.STAGE: [Crawls about roaring, Juno and Venus angry, yet terrified.]

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Hark y' me, Dragon! you're a saucy fellor!
I'll have ye kick'd down stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Vap'ring Ale-swiller!

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Tip him Medusa's Muz!

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Hand here my Aegis!

SP.SPEAKER: Dra.
SP.P: Boh!—I'll indict you all—in Banco Regis.

DIV2.STAGE: [He roars, they scream, Pallas stamps; a rapid Symphony.]

L.HI: Keep the King's Peace within these walls, ho!
Ladies! you can't think it civil,
In Heaven to play the Devil!
You, to keep this holly-rag on!

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: An' if you go to that—you pert Intruder! By whose authority are you thus rude here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Don Jove, our thunder-thumping Caliph, From doze at Council-Board, Upstarting with a bounce, Rapp'd out,—Coxnouns! Call me my Bailiff! Scud, Hermes!—fetch me word, Is Billingsgate transferr'd To Juno's Malepardus?—By the Lord, Her Gossips Throats had need be of Bull-leather.
Tell 'em—I'll come—and tole their Jolls together.

L.HI: I protest,—'tis this Beast—will not rest.
We've no rest,—not the least,—for this Beast.
I'd root th' whole garden—for one fardin.
Yes, I'll firk you, and jerk you, and yerk you.
I'll make you fly—I'll know why.
By cock and pie—you vamp or I.
Hence to your fly—or, Filth! you die.
Jove, by and by,—your suit will try.
A lie—a lie,—just cut and dry.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, a Chamber in the Celestial Palace.
[Momus meets the Dragon in Chains, led to Prison by one of the Furies.]

SP.SPEAKER: MOMUS.
SP.P: AH, ah!—in Crib, Sir Drag.?

SP.SPEAKER: Drag.
SP.P: Now, bail me, Momus!

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: I'd see you hang'd first.

SP.SPEAKER: Drag.
SP.P: Get along,—and be Curst!—Why did I trust a Courtier's Promise?

DIV2.STAGE: AIR I. A Stage Dance Tune.
The Fury lashes him on. Exeunt.
SCENE changes to Jupiter's Hall of Audience.

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—ha! ha! ha!
Three Cats—I left 'em at it,—spitting, —scratch∣ing,
(Seeing Jupiter) Gadso!
Now, What can that wise Nob be hatching?

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: How shall I get this tangled hank un∣ravell'd?
Put to my trumps, and gravell'd!
'Twou'd dumb found, Wizard, Merlin, or Friar Bacon;
Aye, all the Square-caps from Oxford to Pekin.
No making head or tail on't—which way so∣e'er I turn it—
If I know how to act—I'm a sous'd gurnet.
Ha! that Firebrand Erynnis! (Cou'd I but trap her, With what good will I'd strap her!)
I'll be hang'd, but 'twas she that kick'd this dust up,
None but she—mischief-maker! (The Devil take her!)
Amongst my proud leash of Ninnies.
But—I—for her provide will; Yes—I'll have her fairly truss'd up, Tho' the old Trot shou'd mount for't, Who can call me to account for't?
Or, if not strung—she shall—mill-doll—in Bridewell.

L.HI: To bilk him will be braver.

DIV2.STAGE: [Towards the close of the Air, Momus advances to him.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: That's fix'd then.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Yes, yes—I've wound up my bottom.

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: Roundly; like a true Solomon— (aside) of Gotham.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: But how to still their clamours—there's the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: Depute some Mortal for their Arbitrator; 'Twill pull 'em down a peg.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: 'Twill, 'twill—the sluts!
I'll do't—to fiddle-strings 'twill fret their guts.

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: Oh! they'll cajole you with their Ifs and Buts.
Didn't they coax you in your beer to impris'n The Dragon but for claiming what was his'n?

L.HI: Doxies wind you as they please;
Thro' their eyes you then discover,
That the Moon's a huge Green-cheese,

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: I was a green-horn then—no pene∣tration—
But now I'm come to years—

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: Not—of discretion.—

DIV2.STAGE: Mercury enters hastily, and twitches Jupiter's sleeve.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Most Doughty—please edge this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Eh! what mutter y'?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: The Goddesses—at loggerheads—i' th' Buttery.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Fight dog, fight bear—I?—Blood I I've other bus'ness:
Must Jove fit Judge—on Dimples—Snouts—and Pigsnies?
Bid 'em scrub up as clean as hands can make 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: Shou'd they run rust—

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: By Jericho!—I'd flake 'em.—
(to Mercury) Conduct them, you, to Ida—There young Paris
Shall view, and there give Judgment, which most fair is.

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: What?—Paris of Troy, That Hobble-de-Hoy, He Lord Chief Justice constituted! If h'as guts in his brains, or in's skull eyes. Sure, sure, this Heav'n-embroiling Prize Cannot be long disputed.

SP.SPEAKER: Fisher. Pallas and Juno,

L.HI: Never, no never can bear the bell.

SP.L: For Venus herself is a Nonpareil.

DIV2.STAGE: Jupiter and Momus come forward, as con∣tinuing their conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: What comes o'you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Oh! I—after the Inspection—
May call—to hear—which carry'd the Election.

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: Mum!—yonder's Juno— (going)

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Aye,—my Message—snubs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: Now—keep it up—be sure—a few dry rubs
Will give her Majesty—the Mulligrubs.

L.HI: Since 'tis writ in the volume of Fate,
Females must lay their account soon or late;
She must submit has a God to her Mate.
Master you'll be—and your Wife be a slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: How now, Dame Partlet?—
SP.STAGE: Enter Juno, stalking haughtily up to him; her arms a-kimbo.)
SP.P: (aside) Now—she opes her Budget.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: So, Sir! Our cause—you scorn, it seems,—to judge it.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: I wash my hands o't:—woundy ticklish Matters
These!—How decree—'twixt my own Wife and Daughters?

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Then, Sir, who shall?

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Why,—Paris,—Son of Priam,—
Genimede's Coz—a better Judge than I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Finely fobb'd off! Had it been Madam Semele—

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Juno,—go, scold your Maids;—do—mind your Family.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: No, with all Heav'n for my due I'd grapple.
Were there an Orchard; mine were every Apple.

L.HI: With your Wife, Sir, ne'er dispute,
Due to her the choicest fruit,
Due to her the branch and tree;
And you know she'll have her right;
Yes, Sir, Morning Noon, and Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Right!—Stuff!—between us, None has a legal right to it, but Venus.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Fool that I was, my Husband to refer to!

SP.SPEAKER: Venus!
SP.P: —a sneaking kindness—Goat!—for Her too?—

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: My Daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Wert your Mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Why my Pet Lamb Ought not go loose—It should be lodg'd in Bed∣lam.
These Maggots, Child—

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: By each new Trull sup∣planted!

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: I'll be divorc'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: The very Thing I wanted.

L.HI: Let not your Fury gull y';
The Chum you pawn'd your Nuptial
You broke all vows—you hot Bell-swagger!
Act the Swan, act the Bull,
At the Goose, at the Calf.
For a taste of the switch.
Wife Wife those taunts are stae.
Yet you can't say black's her nail.
Yet you urge them tooth and nail
I'll not sit down mum chance.
I'll rove, and take my chance.
You shall see the Devil dance.
Tho' I see the Devil dance.
More Sacks on the Mill!—No, no,

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.

L.HI: Jack must have his Jill—I trow;

SP.L: And, as Jove, I will—ha' fix.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, a Chamber in the Celestial Palace.

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: I Met 'em—Friesland hens! their fea∣thers brustling
All the wrong way.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: That's what they get by bustling On the High-horse with Me—

SP.SPEAKER: Mom.
SP.P: Poor Venus said nought.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: True——But—for my Jezebel, and yond' Miss Dread∣nought—

L.HI: I'll taw them soft as old glove,
The Drabs shall know I'm Czar above;
To maunder at the will of Jove.
Mine are the reins—and to the bit,
Tag, Rag, and Bob-tail, shall submit.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, MOUNT IDA. Paris is discovered admiring his own Finery.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: C'est quelque chose cela—no more a Rustick scrubbish,
Paris at Court has dusted off his Rubbish.

L.HI: But now let me flaunt it,
Rant flirt it, and jaunt it,
Gallant it, and dress it away;
I warrant I carry the day.
Lose thousands, and call it mere Sport;

LG.L: Sweet Paris, the Pink of the Court!

DIV2.STAGE: Paris turns, and spies Mercury advancing. What chap comes here? trick'd out so nicely!
Enter to him Mercury. (He stands bowing at a distance.) Dem' mauvaise honte—So thus—concisely.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.L: By garb, gait, and aspect, you're Francois.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: But whence—and whither now?

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: My Errand At present is—

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: To me—I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: E'en so.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: With my poor person smitten?

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: No, Sir—a matter—You'd scarce hit on.
This Apple—(produces the Golden Apple)

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Aye.

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: (Tho' no nice Fruit 'tis) Has set by the ears three tip-top Beauties.
Th' Inscription—there's the bone—

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: To THE FAIREST!

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: 'Till that point's settled—Heav'n can ne'er rest.—

SP.SPEAKER: Juno,
SP.P: Miss Pallas Venus—stiffly
Lay claim to't—

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Well—mon cher!

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: Why, briefly—
You're nam'd their Judge—

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: A precious bawble To set three Goddesses—at squabble!

L.HI: A Goddess, like an earthly Dame,
And turn from dearest Friend to Foe.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: But why to me this Beauty-reference?

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: You, Sir, Jove knows,—can guess the difference—
Betwixt—a Nymph—and a Nut-cracker—

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Not half so well as he,—th'old Smacker!

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: Him they'd think partial,—interested, Therefore in you his Pow'r is vested.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: What Jeopardy?—My Case quite desperate?—
Can please but one,—two must exasperate!—

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: Do as you like—but—leave off prat∣ing.
You keep their Goddessships a-waiting.

LG.L: I hope, Sir, you'll protect me.

DIV2.STAGE: Re-enter Mercury, leading Juno, whom be an∣nounces most ceremoniously. She advances with over-strained haughtiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: Queen Juno, Sir, (bows) Jove's Con∣sort—

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Less Palaver.
We've other fish to fry—(beckons Mercury away; be sneaks off.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Ma'am,—by your Favour—

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Meat for your Lord!—I thought you better knew me.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: La fiere!—a three-pil'd Prude, consume me!

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Lad, don't you feel yourself, at times, ambitious Of Pow'r—and Wealth?

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Ma foi! they're both delicious.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Both you may have—

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: For me pass Sentence, And you will bless your Stars for our Acquaint∣ance.

LG.L: Then shall the Chiefs from Europe

L.HI: Crouching each to hold thy Stirrup,
Proud to serve thee like Seapoys.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Why—faith—She offers-like a Bid∣der.
Nabob!—Bon ça!—let me—consider: Bengal—a damn'd—long—voyage thither.
(aside) Now un grand Coup—You're warm—and I in Spirits—
(to her) 'Gad, Ma'am, let's use your Husband as he merits.

SP.SPEAKER: Down Derry Derry.

L.HI: Sweet Revenge there is a Clue to,

SP.L: Wou'd you take a Fool's advice,—

L.HI: We may dub him in a trice.

SP.L: Dans le Bon ton—Down derry derry.

DIV2.STAGE: (Juno in furious indignation turns fiercely upon him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Indeed!—'Squire Hotspur!—two words to that Bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: N'importe—There needs no farther arguing.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: To be sent haggling here with such a Puppy!
Well, Jove, remember this, if I ben't up wi' ye.

L.HI: I'll shake your curtains every night,
And you shall tremble with affright;
I'll bounce, I'll flounce, I'll rant and rave,
And you shall be a very slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: Yes, Sir—
Dans le Bon ton,—hey, derry derry.
Dins le Bon ton,
Sur le Gazon,

DIV2.STAGE: (until Mercury re-enters, introducing Pallas. He bows and retires. She stands sullen; Paris hops partly up to kiss her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Servant, my dear,!—

DIV2.STAGE: (She repulses him with a violent push.)

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Since when? Spruce Master Jemmy!

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.STAGE: (aside, his hands on his breast as in pain)
SP.P: That Peg she had from Broughton—demme!
Well, Joan of Arc!—my frumpish Missy
You might, as well ha' let me kiss ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Paris, no Airs—That Pippin, without musing,
Adjudge to me—

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Bon;—for your Skill in bruising.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: I'll make your Fortune:—Call me else, Canary.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: My Fortune, Miss!—

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Ay, in the Milita—ry.

SP.SPEAKER: Bates.

L.HI: Shall gain thee store of plunder!
Ne'er saw such piles of Mammon!

SP.L: Raise, young Paris, raise thy name!

L.HI: Away, away to Wealth and Fame!

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Zauns, Miss—What see you in my Figure, As if I lov'd to draw a Trigger?

L.HI: Let Heroes delight in the toils of the war,
In maims, blood, and bruises and blows;
Not a sword, but a sword-knot rejoices the Fair:
And what art rough Soldiers to Beaux?
Away then with laurels! come Beauty and Love,
And silence the trumpet and drum;
Let me with soft Myrtle my brows bear inwove,

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Dastard!—Be henceforth, (since you're for that duty)
No Officer of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Ni vous—my Beauty.
Now, Merc'ry!—let the Cyprian Belle come.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mercury, hands out Pallas, and introduces Venus; then bows, and exit. She advances, smirking Paris, tho' struck with her beauty, trips to salute her with his usual pertness.
SP.P: Ay this! (to her) Permettez-moi! (kisses her)

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: And welcome.
SP.STAGE: (leering, and chucking him under the chin)
SP.P: My Paris! can you love?

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: No foolish item.
Yes, Ma'am—kind souls!—I never slight'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: Well, there's a Judge—one Menelaus—in Sparta;
(A Judge's crest is—Horns—by Magna Charta)
That Judge, he hath a wife—that Wife hight Nelly,
But such a Nell!—at ev'ry glance
The cockles of your heart would dance,
Warm'd as if by Vermicelli.

L.HI: Thou of heroes shalt lead the van!
Faint heart ne'er fair lady won.
Be bold, and play the Man!
Oh, such bliss you've no idea;

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.P: Agreed—touchez!—Now for a Barrel Of Golden Pippins—We shall never quarrel.
I'll call the Ladies in that went hence.
SP.STAGE: (Takes the Apple in his hand, crosses the Stage, and calls aloud)
SP.P: Mercury!—I'm going to Pass Sentence.

DIV2.STAGE: (Enter on one Side Mercury, ushering in Juno and Pallas; on the other, Venus alone.)

L.HI: Rests here Placing it as a Bouquet in Venus's Bosom.—tho' Losers mutiny.

SP.L: Fair ye to the bone are;—

DIV2.STAGE: (Juno and Pallas walk to and fro, stomachful; Venus and Paris bowing and curtsying. Mercury stands tittering.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: Buzzard!—in real Beauty, Ignoramus!

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: That lewd Trull's Person was his Fee to bam us.

SP.SPEAKER: Juno.
SP.P: For this,—an old house o'er! your Sconce I'll tumble.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.
SP.P: Poltroon!—Since War you dread, its Din shall rumble
In both your Ears—

SP.SPEAKER: Merc.
SP.P: Ladies!—You're not to grumble.—

DIV2.STAGE: AIR XII. QUARTETTO. Fye now, prithee, John.

L.HI: You no title bad—no, nor you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pal.

L.HI: And he's a rogue—has cheated us!

SP.L: But Pallas won't be treated thus:

L.HI: A Pippin, is not worth this fuss!
Do, you fool? observe my face,
My shape and air, and every grace:
The brightest Queen that e'er was seen!

DIV2.STAGE: (A furious Symphony; then enter hastily Jupiter, rageously angry, the thunder-bolt in his hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Ye spiteful Jades!—threat not my Puny Judge, else
For him I will, myself, take up the Cudgels—The proudest She that with him dares to meddle, I'll make dance Barnaby—without a Fiddle!

SP.SPEAKER: Galluppi.
SP.L: He judg'd it just as I did.—

L.HI: Ye cou'd not all Three have it;

SP.L: He to the FAIREST gave it.

L.HI: That he had Eyes to see,
And that the Truth he spoke?
If still ye're stiff and sturdy,

SP.L: Look to't—I'm at a word wi' ye;—

L.HI: And now my mind ye know.

SP.SPEAKER: Ven.
SP.P: The Dragon!—Dear Papa! have some regard on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup.
SP.P: Well mov'd! (nodding to Mercury) Go, set the Dragon free—I pardon him.

DIV2.STAGE: (Exit Mercury. Enter Dragon; making profound obeisance to all.)
JUPITER, JUNO, PALLAS, VENUS, PARIS, DRAGON.

L.HI: I ne'er shou'd ha' grudg'd it.
Why to me this mortal hatred?
Why to me this spleen inveterate?
Why to her this mortal hatred?
Why to her such spleen inveterate?
Beauty's my sole Gift of Nature;
Thank her, she cou'd give no greater.
I have no patience with such flirts.
Ne'er heed. We'll stick in both their skirts.
Blood! don't again my passion rouze.
He's your Papa, Miss, and your Spouse.
If you will not be cool,
I have for Scolds a School,
You see Sir, we are cool.
We shall not need that School.
They will not need that School.
You see, Sir, they are cool.

SP.SPEAKER: Jup., Juno., Pal., Ven., Par., Dra.

L.HI: This day shall be High Jubilee

SP.SPEAKER: Jup., Juno., Pal., Ven., Par., Dra.

L.HI: Let this day be High Jubilee

SP.SPEAKER: Jup., Juno., Pal., Ven., Par., Dra.

DIV1.HEAD: ERRATUM.
DIV1.P: P. 8. for "Scene changes to a Wild Heath"—read "Scens changes to a Wood."
